title: The 'Mexico' show at the Dallas Museum of Art looks like a blockbuster in the making
text:

Buzz is a big deal in the world of art museums, and buzz is the word, as in there's plenty of it, for "México 1900-1950: Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo, José Clemente Orozco, and the Avant-Garde," which opened Sunday at the Dallas Museum of Art. 
New DMA director Agustín Arteaga, who came here last July from Mexico City, spoke optimistically this week of the show's drawing power, saying: 
"We have a history of successful exhibitions at the DMA, an example is last year's 'Jackson Pollock: Blind Spots' exhibition, which had an attendance of more than 67,500 visitors. We hope that 'México' will be as appealing to our visitors and will match, and hopefully exceed, this success." Leslie Marrufozo (front) waits in line for the "Mexico 1900-1950: Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo, Jose Clemente Orozco, and the Avant-Garde" exhibit at the Dallas Museum of Art in Dallas on Tuesday, March 14, 2017. Rose Baca/Staff Photographer 
So far, the exhibition, which includes multiple works by such acclaimed artists as Frida Kahlo, has lured 5,878 visitors through the turnstiles, as of the close of business Tuesday, a figure that includes preview days and opening events. The number of visitors on Sunday, the show's official opening day, reached 2,530. 
That got us to thinking about the top 10 special paid exhibitions for attendance. These are the most highly attended shows at the DMA since 2000: 
1. "Tutankhamun and the Golden Age of the Pharaohs" — 621,238 visitors; Oct. 3, 2008, through May 17, 2009 (32 weeks) 
2. "Splendors of China's Forbidden City: The Glorious Reign of Emperor Qianlong" — 161,459 visitors; Nov. 21, 2004, through May 29, 2005 (23 weeks) 
3. "Van Gogh's Sheaves of Wheat" — 129,285 visitors; Oct. 22, 2006. through Jan. 7, 2007 (12 weeks) 
4. "The Fashion World of Jean Paul Gaultier: From the Sidewalk to the Catwalk" — 114,986 visitors; Nov. 13, 2011, through Feb. 12, 2012 (13 weeks) 
5. "J.M.W. Turner" — 91,147 visitors; Feb. 10, 2008, through May 18, 2008 (23 weeks) 
6. "Matisse: Painter as Sculptor" (shared exhibition with the Nasher Sculpture Center) — 76,045 visitors; Jan. 21, 2007, through April 29, 2007 (13 weeks) 
7. "Louis Comfort Tiffany" — 71,483 visitors; May 28, 2006, through Sept. 3, 2006 (13 weeks) 
8. "Renoir and Algeria" — 71,142 visitors; June 8, 2003, through Aug. 31, 2003 (13 weeks) 
9. "Jackson Pollock: Blind Spots" — 67,749 visitors; Nov. 20, 2015, through March 20, 2016 (17 weeks) 
10. "Bluebonnets and Beyond: Julian Onderdonk" — 64,915 visitors; March 23, 2008, through July 20, 2008 (16 weeks)
